title: Speech acts: Constative and performative - Colleen Glenney Boggs

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a constative and a performative sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: A constative is a sentence that commands, and a performative is a sentence that describes.

options.label: B
options.text: A constative is a sentence that describes, and a performative is a sentence that commands.

options.label: C
options.text: A constative is a sentence that is, and a performative is a sentence that does.

options.label: D
options.text: A constative is a sentence that does, and a performative is a sentence that is.

multiple-choice.question: What does the sign "The park closes at 6 p.m." represent?
What is the purpose of the sign "Recycle"?

options.label: C
options.text: To request people to put their trash into the proper receptacle.

options.label: D
options.text: To inform people about the importance of recycling.

multiple-choice.question: What are felicity conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: The rules under which a performative can be enacted.

options.label: B
options.text: The conditions under which a constative can be enacted.

options.label: C
options.text: The conditions under which a sentence can be understood.

options.label: D
options.text: The conditions under which a sentence can be executed.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a speech act?
What is the purpose of the words "I do" in a wedding ceremony?

options.label: B
options.text: To command the couple to get married.

options.label: C
options.text: To request the couple to get married.

options.label: D
options.text: To act as a speech act that causes the couple to marry.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if the mayor showed up to the wedding and said, "By the power vested in me as mayor of the city, I name this gazebo 'The Mayor's Pizza Palace'"?

options.label: A
options.text: The name of the gazebo would not change.

options.label: B
options.text: The name of the gazebo would change, but only temporarily.

options.label: C
options.text: The name of the gazebo would change, and it would be known by its new name.

options.label: D
options.text: The name of the gazebo would change, but only if the mayor has the proper authority.

multiple-choice.question: What are the felicity conditions for a performative sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: Proper authority, understanding, clarity, and execution.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if a rowdy group of teenagers races to the high dive and ignores the "No running" sign?

options.label: A
options.text: They would be praised for their speed.

options.label: B
options.text: They would be warned by the lifeguard.

options.label: C
options.text: They would face the consequences of breaking the performative.

options.label: D
options.text: They would be banned from the pool.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: The power of words as actions.

options.label: D
options.text: The difference between constatives and performatives.

title: The most groundbreaking scientist you've never heard of - Addison Anderson

multiple-choice.question: Who is Nicolas Steno and why is he important in the field of geology?

options.label: A
options.text: He is a Danish geologist who discovered the rock cycle.

options.label: B
options.text: He is a scientist who expanded and connected concepts of Earth, life, and understanding.

options.label: C
options.text: He is a philosopher who wrote about the history of the Earth.

options.label: D
options.text: He is an English geologist who studied plate tectonics.

multiple-choice.question: What was Nicolas Steno's profession before becoming a geologist?
What did Nicolas Steno discover in animal skulls that challenged Descartes' idea?

options.label: A
options.text: A duct that sends saliva to the mouth.

options.label: C
options.text: A bone that connects the skull to the spine.

options.label: D
options.text: A nerve that connects the brain.

multiple-choice.question: What was the Grand Duke of Tuscany's role in Nicolas Steno's research?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a sponsor of Steno's expeditions.

options.label: B
options.text: He was a patron of Steno's work.

options.label: C
options.text: He had Steno dissect a shark.

options.label: D
options.text: He helped Steno publish his findings.

multiple-choice.question: What did Nicolas Steno argue about the origin of tongue stones?

options.label: B
options.text: They were snake tongues petrified by Saint Paul.

options.label: C
options.text: They were shark teeth that became embedded in rock.

options.label: D
options.text: They were rocks that were shaped like tongues.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept that Nicolas Steno planted seeds for in his research?
Who were the English uniformitarian geologists who studied current rates of erosion and sedimentation?
What theory was developed in the mid-twentieth century that combined the rock cycle with plate tectonics?

options.label: C
options.text: The theory of the Earth's molten crust.

options.label: D
options.text: The theory of the Earth's quaking surface.

multiple-choice.question: How did Nicolas Steno's research contribute to the development of biology?

options.label: A
options.text: He discovered the origin of life on Earth.

options.label: B
options.text: He studied the evolution of species.

options.label: C
options.text: He argued that species change over time through natural processes.

options.label: D
options.text: He developed the theory of evolution through natural selection.

multiple-choice.question: What is Nicolas Steno's maxim that he believed was the pursuit of truth?

options.label: A
options.text: "The search for truth is the pursuit of beauty of the unknown."

options.label: B
options.text: "The truth is what we see, more truth is what we know, most truth is what we don't."

options.label: C
options.text: "The pursuit of truth is the pursuit of beauty."

options.label: D
options.text: "The truth is what we believe, not what we see."

title: Was Leonardo da Vinci dyslexic?

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way Leonardo da Vinci wrote in his journals?

options.label: A
options.text: He wrote in a single line without punctuation.

options.label: B
options.text: He wrote in a mirror way, with letters inverted.

options.label: C
options.text: He wrote with his non-dominant hand.

options.label: D
options.text: He wrote in a circular motion.

multiple-choice.question: According to Professor Maryanne Wolf, why did Leonardo da Vinci write in a mirror way?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he was a left-handed person and it was easier for him.

options.label: B
options.text: Because he discovered that it was something he did with ease.

options.label: C
options.text: Because he was trying to create a deliberate form of code.

options.label: D
options.text: Because he was dyslexic and his brain was wired to do so.

multiple-choice.question: What is dyslexia, according to Professor Maryanne Wolf?

options.label: A
options.text: An inherited learning disability that impairs people's reading and writing skills.

options.label: B
options.text: A condition that affects only left-handed people.

options.label: C
options.text: A condition that affects only right-handed people.

options.label: D
options.text: A condition that has nothing to do with reading and writing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of Professor Maryanne Wolf's experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: To test the theory that left-handed people are better at mirror writing.

options.label: B
options.text: To test the theory that dyslexics are better at mirror writing.

options.label: C
options.text: To test the theory that mirror writing is a deliberate form of code.

options.label: D
options.text: To test the theory that left-handed dyslexics are more naturally able to mirror write.

multiple-choice.question: What did Professor Maryanne Wolf's experiment indicate?

options.label: A
options.text: That left-handed people are faster at mirror writing.

options.label: B
options.text: That dyslexics are faster at mirror writing.

options.label: C
options.text: That left-handed dyslexics are faster at mirror writing.

options.label: D
options.text: That mirror writing has nothing to do with neurological processes.

multiple-choice.question: What does Professor Maryanne Wolf believe about Leonardo da Vinci's mirror writing?

options.label: A
options.text: That it was a deliberate form of code.

options.label: B
options.text: That it was a natural neurological process.

options.label: C
options.text: That it was a result of his left-handedness.

options.label: D
options.text: That it was a result of his dyslexia.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the human brain's two hemispheres in relation to mirror writing?

options.label: A
options.text: The left hemisphere governs our ability to recognize sequences of words and letters.

options.label: B
options.text: The right hemisphere governs our ability to recognize sequences of words and letters.

options.label: C
options.text: The left hemisphere is used to analyze space and geometrical shapes and forms.

options.label: D
options.text: The right hemisphere is used to analyze space and geometrical shapes and forms.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between dyslexia and mirror writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Dyslexics are more likely to be left-handed.

options.label: B
options.text: Dyslexics are more likely to be right-handed.

options.label: C
options.text: Dyslexics are more likely to be able to mirror write.

options.label: D
options.text: Dyslexics are less likely to be able to mirror write.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of Professor Maryanne Wolf's research on mirror writing?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the neurological processes behind mirror writing.

options.label: B
options.text: To understand the relationship between mirror writing and dyslexia.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the relationship between mirror writing and handedness.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the relationship between mirror writing and reading and writing skills.

multiple-choice.question: What does Professor Maryanne Wolf's research suggest about Leonardo da Vinci's mirror writing?

options.label: A
options.text: That it was a deliberate form of code.

options.label: B
options.text: That it was a natural neurological process.

options.label: C
options.text: That it was a result of his handedness.

options.label: D
options.text: That it was a result of his dyslexia.

title: Are Elvish, Klingon, Dothraki and Na’vi real languages?

multiple-choice.question: What is a "conlang"?

options.label: B
options.text: A collection of fabricated slang like Nadsat lingo.

options.label: C
options.text: A constructed language, more than a code or slang.

options.label: D
options.text: A language that is not used in any country.

multiple-choice.question: What makes a conlang a real language?

options.text: The number of words it has.

options.label: C
options.text: Both the vocabulary and the grammar of the language.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither the vocabulary nor the grammar of the language.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to change over time.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to be understood by people from different cultures.

options.label: C
options.text: The development of Elvish from Quenya and Sindarin.

options.label: D

options.text: The development of Elvish from Quenya and Sindarin.

options.label: B
options.text: The development of French, Spanish, and Italian from Latin.

options.label: C
options.text: The development of English from Old English.

options.label: D
options.text: The development of Klingon from Dothraki.

options.text: Elvish is a more developed language.

options.label: B
options.text: Elvish is a less developed language.

options.label: C
options.text: Elvish is a hobby rather than an attempt to create a spoken language.

options.label: D
options.text: Elvish is a language that is not used in any country.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process of creating a language that is based on guesses about what a language might have looked like?

title: Your genes are not your fate - Dean Ornish

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to change our genes?
What happens to the brain when we eat healthier, manage stress, exercise, and love more?

options.label: C
options.text: It gets more blood flow and oxygen.

options.label: D
options.text: It gets less blood flow and oxygen.

options.label: C
options.text: It gets more blood flow and ages less quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: It gets less blood flow and ages more quickly.

multiple-choice.question: What can be reversed by making lifestyle changes?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: We can't do anything about our genes.

options.label: D
options.text: Our genes are not our fate, and we can change how they are expressed by making lifestyle changes.

options.label: C
options.text: In the 1960s, when the rich world helped develop Africa.

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.text: Because they are not used to the atmosphere.

options.label: C
options.text: Because their body has adapted to the weightlessness of space.
